28.text: Hello. 28 teams qualified to appear in this series.

32.text: 12 fell by the wayside during the first round.

34.text: Seven more have bitten the dust during this second round,

38.text: which ends tonight. Only one place remains in the quarterfinals

41.text: and both tonight's teams want it.

43.text: Well, they think they do now.

45.text: The four from St John's College, Oxford, achieved

47.text: one of the strongest scores of the first round

49.text: when they beat Bristol University by 255 points to 125.

54.text: They missed very little and did well

56.text: on dungeons and dragons in English literature and biblical book clouds.

60.text: And they were very happy with some gruesome depictions

64.text: of what Judith did to Holofernes.

66.text: With an average age of 19, let's meet the St John's team again.

70.text: Hi, my name is Alex Harries.

72.text: I'm originally from South Wales and I'm reading History.

75.text: Hello, my name is Charlie Clegg, I'm from Glasgow

80.text:
- This is their captain.

83.text: I'm from Mill Hill in north London and I study History and Russian.

88.text: I'm from Uxbridge in Middlesex and I'm reading Chemistry.

99.text: throughout their first-round match against Sussex University,

106.text: They may need to brush up their Shakespeare,

109.text: but they recognised Edmund Burke, WH Auden

111.text: and the Velvet Underground as if they were all old pals.

115.text: With an average age of 28, let's meet the Queen's, Belfast, team again.

154.text: What word denotes in general terms a receptacle for a grocery item,

159.text: in computing, a decoy website to draw hackers or spammers,

163.text: in espionage, a form of recruitment through seduction,

170.text: No. And you lose five points.

174.text: a place that draws a large number of visitors.

183.text: OK, you get a set of bonuses on the human figure in British art.

192.text: comprises the work The Maybe, first displayed in 1995

206.text:
- Tilda Swinton? 
- Did she go in for things like this? 
- Go for it?

213.text: 100 life-sized human figures created by Antony Gormley

216.text: for a work entitled Another Place took up permanent residence in 2007

231.text: I thought it was Crosby beach. That's Merseyside.

241.text: by Flanagan and Allen comprise the Singing Sculpture of 1969,

251.text:
- Gilbert and George. 
- Correct. 10 points for this.

253.text: "His philosophy is so odd that one would not have expected him

257.text: "to be able to get sane men to accept it, but he did.

259.text: "He set it out with so much obscurity

262.text: "that people thought it must be profound."

264.text: These words of Bertrand Russell refer to which philosopher?

267.text: Born in Stuttgart in 1770, he's especially noted

270.text: for his three-stage process of dialectical reasoning.

280.text: Your first bonuses, Queen's, are on apps.

288.text: was bought by the cloud storage firm Dropbox

290.text: for a rumoured 100 million the following month?

305.text: and allows users to type out a short confessional message,

309.text: overlay it on a related image and share it anonymously?

323.text: over their smartphones, which mobile messaging service

326.text: was bought by Facebook for 19 billion in February 2014?

342.text: In Shaw's Pygmalion, Henry Higgins lived at 27a.

345.text: At number 50, Elizabeth Barrett was kept a virtual prisoner by her father...

358.text: Coined in 1922 by the US sociologist William Ogburn,

363.text: what two-word term refers to the gap that develops

375.text:
- Culture gap. 
- It's the cultural lag, is the term.

379.text: Secondly, what term was introduced by US sociologist William G Sumner

386.text: He defined it as the view of things

388.text: in which one's own group is the centre of everything

391.text: and all others are scaled and rated with reference to it?

420.text: of their developmental years outside their parents' culture?

443.text: and former territories of the moribund Western Roman Empire.

449.text: who made the indicated migration are commonly known.

464.text: this time all made by Germanic tribes

466.text: into the territories of the collapsing Western Roman Empire.

469.text: Five points for each tribe you can name. Firstly...

482.text:
- The Visigoths. 
- That is correct, yes. Secondly...

- The Goths. 
- No, that's the Vandals.

499.text: You can see they took Carthage there. And finally...

510.text: Or is it the Jutes? Jutes?

512.text:
- Jutes? 
- It is the Jutes, yes. 10 points for this.

515.text: Examples being found in Texas, Florida, Alaska, Oklahoma and Idaho,

524.text: with a land border on at least two sides,

527.text: extending out from the geographical body of the state?

529.text: The term refers to a part of a household...?

679.text: with which the general quintic equation can be associated?

688.text: I think it's a bit late for Pascal, isn't it?

- De Moivre? 
- Yes.

699.text:
